message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and sunburn history suggest Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). Detection of antibodies directed against Nuclear Sm proteins is highly specific for SLE. Antibodies against cell nucleus and single-stranded DNA can be seen in other non-SLE autoimmune disorders. Antibodies against Fc region of IgG are seen in Rheumatoid Arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of sunburn and symptoms suggest that the patient has systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can be confirmed by the detection of antibodies directed against Nuclear Sm proteins. The other options are associated with different conditions and are less specific for SLE.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, such as joint pain and muscle aches, suggest systemic lupus erythematosus. The specific antibodies used to diagnose SLE include anti-nuclear antibody (ANA), anti-double-stranded-DNA antibody (anti-dsDNA), anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibody, anti-Ro antibody, anti-La antibody, and anti-RNP antibody. Among the options, only nuclear Sm proteins are specific for SLE.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of joint pain and muscle aches suggest a connective tissue disorder, and the sunburn may have triggered an autoimmune reaction. The presence of multiple nontender ulcers on the oral mucosa suggests systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Detection of antibodies directed against nuclear Sm proteins is 100% specific for SLE.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and sunburn suggest the patient has systemic lupus erythematosus. The detection of antibodies directed against Nuclear Sm proteins is most specific for this condition. Other options are associated with other autoimmune diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and recent sunburn suggest Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). Anti-Nuclear Antibody (ANA) is not specific for SLE, but Anti-Sm antibodies are highly specific for SLE. Therefore, detection of Anti-Sm antibodies is the most specific for this patient’s condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest that she has systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and antibodies against nuclear Sm proteins are specific to SLE. All other options are associated with other diseases like Sjogren’s syndrome and rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including joint pain and oral ulcers, suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Detection of antibodies against nuclear Sm proteins is highly specific for SLE. Antibodies against cell nucleus and single-stranded DNA are also seen in SLE but are not as specific. Antibodies against Fc region of IgG are seen in various autoimmune diseases.

The detection of antibodies against nuclear Sm proteins is highly specific for SLE. Anti-cell nucleus and anti-single stranded DNA antibodies are also present in SLE but are less specific. Anti-Fc region of IgG antibodies are not specific for SLE.

Detection of antibodies directed against Nuclear Sm proteins is most specific for SLE. Cell nucleus and single-stranded DNA antibodies are not specific for SLE, and the detection of Fc region of IgG antibodies is not associated with SLE.
